technical_concept: Git moves your files between four areas: Working Directory (your files on disk), Staging Area (what you've chosen to include in the next commit), Local Repository (your committed history in .git/), and Remote Repository (GitHub). Every Git command is just moving something between these areas. Your desktop GUI hid the Staging Area from you — that's the key piece you were missing.

code_example.code:
┌──────────────┐  git add   ┌──────────────┐  git commit  ┌──────────────┐  git push   ┌──────────────┐
│              │ ─────────► │              │ ───────────► │              │ ──────────► │              │
│  Working Dir │            │ Staging Area │              │  Local Repo  │             │  Remote Repo │
│  (your files)│ ◄───────── │  (the index) │              │   (.git/)    │ ◄────────── │   (GitHub)   │
└──────────────┘ git restore└──────────────┘              └──────────────┘  git fetch  └──────────────┘

                  git status tells you where each file currently lives
                  git pull  =  git fetch + git merge

challenge.task: Create a file called 'notes.txt' with the content 'first draft', stage it with git add, then commit it with the message 'Add notes'.
challenge.hint: You need three steps: echo to create the file, git add to stage it, and git commit -m to commit. Chain them with &&.
challenge.solution: echo 'first draft' > notes.txt && git add notes.txt && git commit -m 'Add notes'

dialogue.line: Come, my friend. You tell me you know Git — that you have been using it daily. Is that so?
Yes, Socrates. I commit, I push, I pull. I've been using GitHub Desktop for over a year.
Excellent! Then tell me — when you click 'Commit' in your tool, where exactly does your code go?
To... the repository?
Which repository? The one on your machine, or the one on GitHub?
I... hmm. I suppose the local one first? Then I push to GitHub?
Good — you are already halfway there. Now, your tool has a checkbox beside each file before you commit. What is that?
That's to select which files to include in the commit.

Precisely. And in the terminal, that selection is its own distinct place — the Staging Area. Your tool hid it behind a checkbox. Look at the diagram: four areas, four arrows. Every Git command you will ever learn simply moves files between them.
So 'git add' is the checkbox? And 'git commit' is clicking the Commit button?

Now you see it. 'git add' moves a file from your Working Directory to the Staging Area. 'git commit' moves everything staged into the Local Repository. 'git push' sends it to the Remote. And 'git status' — that is your compass. It tells you exactly where each file lives right now.
And 'git pull'?

That is the reverse journey — from Remote to your machine. It fetches the commits, then merges them into your Working Directory. Two steps disguised as one. Now — let us not merely talk about it. Show me the complete journey of a file, from creation to committed history.
Before you learned the GUI, Git was simple. After you learned the GUI, Git was complicated. After you learn the terminal... Git will be simple again.
Master, I have used Git for a long time. Why do I still feel confused?
Because your tool showed you a window into a house, but never the house itself. Tell me — how many places can a file be?
Two? On my computer and on GitHub?

Four. Study the diagram. A file begins in the Working Directory — your garden of raw earth. With 'git add', it enters the Staging Area — the place of intention, where you decide what the next moment of history will contain.
My GUI never mentioned a Staging Area.
It was there. Hidden behind a checkbox. The GUI chose simplicity over understanding. We choose understanding.
And the third and fourth areas?

With 'git commit', your intention becomes history — stored in the Local Repository, the .git folder on your own machine. With 'git push', that history travels to the Remote — GitHub, where others may receive it.
So every command is just... moving between four places?
Now you hold the whole of Git in one thought. When lost, return to the four areas and ask: where am I, and where do I wish to go?
How do I know where I am?
'git status'. It is the still water that reflects truth. Use it before every action, after every action. Now — walk the path yourself. Create a file, carry it through the areas, and make it history.
